subject: Creativity
title: Ancient Greek Comedy: When Theater Got Rude
description: A micro-lesson that makes Ancient Greek Comedy: When Theater Got Rude usable.

hook.text: Aristophanes wrote a play where women seized the government by going on a sex strike. In 411 BC.

buildup.text: Greek comedy ('komos' = revel) began at festivals of Dionysus, where masked performers mocked politicians.

discovery.text: Comedy was democratic free speech in action. Aristophanes publicly mocked Socrates, war leaders, and demagogues.

twist.text: The Greeks saw comedy as equally important as tragedy â€” not lesser.

climax.text: Modern political satire, sitcoms, and stand-up comedy all trace directly to Greek comedy's 2,400-year-old invention.

punchline.text: The Greeks invented democracy AND comedy. Probably not a coincidence.

quiz.question: What was the primary function of comedy in ancient Greece?
options: Publicly mocking politicians, philosophers, and power through democratic free speech
